comments.commentBody: I agree!... This will make what we in the South call a "mess of beans!"
A pound of dried beans for 4-8 servings of what would appear to be an appetizer? Those are some hefty slices of toast!

It is shocking that in the medical sector, we pay astronomical costs for a very low quality product. It's a race to the bottom.  We would never overpay for a terrible product or go to an incompetent surgeon if there was transparency in medical care quality and medical billing.  Transparency would weed out incompetent, dishonest doctors with out-of-date skills and reduce medical costs via enabling consumers to comparison price shop for medical care. My surgeon was a medical fraud who instead of performing the consented to and long planned modern, minimally-invasive surgery, just did an old-fashioned, open procedure, butcher job for no medical or anatomical reason. She did it because she fraudulently misrepresented her skills and experience. My surgeon's hospital then billed thousands of dollars to my health insurance company for the unused laparoscopic surgery tools and materials that just sat in the OR in their wrapping while my doctor butchered me with her scalpel, breaching my consent. Medical fraud and malpractice have enormous unnecessary costs. When patients are injured, the irony is that they must then pay all the enormous medical bills to treat the iatrogenic injuries. The worse the quality of care, the more doctors, medical groups, and hospitals make.
It is fraud and it is assault.  Why don't more people in health care go to prison?

This is an outrage. Americans are hard working people. We lower our heads and forge through all kinds of exploitations that are the current reality of our financial and social system. We are being abused by a for-profit, greedy, unscrupulous health care system. It is a joke that we are exceptional or that we are the best country in the world. If we were, we would have affordable, quality healthcare for all our citizens as a right. We are fooling ourselves.
When will we demand change? When will we have enough? Until when will we have to give up our homes, our future and our children's futures so that a select few make money off our misfortune? This is such a sad statement.

Excellent comment.  In fact, most of the land in this country is not "our land" at all.  We spend our lives on a few tiny patches of land, connected by thin ribbons of public access (roads and highways).  Private ownership of vast tracts of land effectively removes it from being "ours" and greatly restricts any "freedom" we might think we have.

This is a great comment.  The same thought occurs to me every day as I cycle a narrow public trail squeezed behind empty, zillion dollar Mcmansions circling Lake Washington. Our most treasured public resources are literally fenced in by the few who can afford it, but rarely appreciate it.

I often reflect on property ownership as I drive along the beautiful lakes and waterways where I live and must strain to find a view among the competing architectural altars to each owner's success story. Small slivers of "public access" points do exist, but are pathetically inadequate.

Homeowners along one lake took it upon themselves to appropriate publicly-owned former railroad land along one entire side of a lake, and when the county initiated plans to convert the rails to a trail for public use, the homeowners were enraged that their illegally appropriated public property was repatriated, and that the "public" would be walking near their waterfront homes. They became so aggressive, that County officials brought police with them when they went to survey the property.

The rapid appropriation and sense of entitlement by the elites of our most scenic areas--and political influence that allowed this, is a tragic visual reminder of our rapidly failing Democracy.

After reading all the comments, I used sumac & mint at the end, to make it more like the Turkish version.  Served it with crustini with tomato/basil/buffalo mozzarella, to bring in another Mediterranean flavor.  Fabulous and fun weeknight dinner!

Exactly. Unfortunately, the majority of people (voters) who are fascinated and swayed by the drama of famous people's lives are the one's that need to read and heed Frank's opinion piece. I am reminded of the line by Al Pacino in "The Recruit"-- "Nothing is what is seems."
We do care if she is using him as a campaign prop.  Same goes for Cruz' kids - fair game if he uses them.
Agreed. Pointless piece.

Bruni has intentesting things to say from time to time. This is not one of those times. Totally pointless opinion piece, it tells us nothing of interest about the Clintons. We already know that they do not spat in public and how they deal with each other in private it is their affair, not ours. Should Hillary condemn him in public for his escapades to establish her bona fides with women? Why should anyone care?  What we should care about is what public policies she intends to pursue. How she handles her husband is not our business.

Ownership has its limits, but that does not necessitate the elimination of ownership altogether.

Through representatives society can legislate the limit of ownership to prevent an individual from amassing wealth or industry or property to an extent that oppresses the majority. Anti-monopoly laws were created to address that concern.

To 'eliminate' private property is, in reality, to place it under the private control of select politicians, bureaucrats, and their cronies. This is how human nature actually works, and a quick read through Orwell's novel, Animal Farm, is a primer for consideration of this fact. If one prefers historic proof, the Soviet Union provided an object lesson.

The best news for those of us who know about that sham that is big-time college sports. Now if only the cable television cartel would let me drop all my sports channels, especially ESPN, I could save lots of money. Instead I may have to do what my adult son has already done: cut the cable cord.

"...the Times reported the initiation of Monday Night Football has a ho-hum matter"
This is a classic apples to oranges comparison isn't it? What MNF offered was an alternative to whatever else was being broadcast on a night when the most likely entertainment options involved watching television in the first place. New Year's eve plans are often made weeks and months in advance. Why not do whatever one wants on that night and record and watch the games later (if at all), commercial free? Win, win except for whoever's showing them live.

The semifinals are a big deal for college football fans, but there is no tradition yet.   When there are office pools and big money wagers and New Year's eve/playoff parties, that will change. Remember, the Times reported the initiation of Monday Night Football has a ho-hum matter.
That WAR stat is perhaps the best evidence we have that Griffey didn't juice.
Using WAR, Griffey accumulated over 90% of his productivity by 2000 and less than 10% thereafter.

Motivational speech from a pulpit will not be received well by Coughlin's sports media as was the case with his modern players and coaches taken as a whole.  The message was stale and cynical, traits also embodied in the Manning and JPP contract extensions.

When the return is so disproportionate to the risk capital will inevitably flow to that market.  As long as sports continue to treat doping as a minor infringement, greed and desperation will keep the doping business alive and well.

How do you know if Peyton Manning is a 'womanizer' or not? And what does that have to do with whether he used HGH or not? I'm wondering more about the record breaking year he had a year after many wondered if he'd ever step foot on a football field again.

In defense of WADA, WADA was not even formed until November 10, 1999  and were not a functioning body until 2002. You can blame the IOC for Andreea Raducan's 2000 loss of a gold medal but not WADA. I would blame Andreea's  doctor for this disqualification. WADA did fund the Independent Commission's investigation of Russia which led to Russia Track and Field being suspended and presently ineligible for the 2016 Olympics. The Independent Commission investigation also led to indictment against former IAAF president Lamine Diack. I do not call these actions "distractions" in the battle against doping. The second half of the Commission's investigation is yet to be released. It should be noted that  the Independent Commission recommends WADA develop and implement a whistleblower assistance and protection policy. As you state most doping scandals are uncovered by insiders (whistleblower). I see WADA as the only entity working toward reducing the stranglehold that doping has on sports world wide.
So, you didn't find any of that suspicious?  A lot of questionable behavior and nobody talking.  I believe the saying is "the silence is deafening."

Deborah Davies, while a guest on CNN's "Reliable Sources" Sunday morning, said Charles David Sly was not al-Jazeera's only source who alleged Peyton's wife, Ashley, received multiple shipments of HGH from The Guyer Institute in Indianapolis
Right, because no one has ever lied in court while under oath.

good reporting! as others feel, there's something here, stay on it. I had couple serious non-pro athletefriends who paid big $$$ to work out and train at a place he used to run and the guy does know his advanced training methods. there's 100 gyms nationwide where you can have them craft a program tailored to you. all it takes is fat $$$ and most non-pros dont have it or have the time it takes to train to stay on that edge to win a triathlon, power lifting or cross fit competition. its all specific training now with the key word being recovery, hence HGH. no more cycling dianabol or maybe stanozanol for 6 weeks on and off and a flush before you p test. its your own cocktail of recovery enhancers and drugs. all it takes is $$$.
what I dont understand is how all these big, fat strong beasts in the nfl move as they do. I see more fat bellies and butts on sunday anymore than you can shake a stick at. if many of them just lost 15# of body fat they'd be better players. the guy deadlifting 405# in the website pic is where we non-pros all want to go. and some of us can still do it too without drugs.

Right now his wife's HIPPA  protection is what is keeping the NFL from linking Manning to HGH. Yes I believe he would have it sent to his wife. If he were innocent do you think his wife's medical privacy concerns would be worth giving up his multi million dollar public image and his entry into the hall of fame? Lets see Ashley's  medical records and explanation for using HGH. Or even have a reliable third party review of Ashley records to verify they are valid without disclosing details. We need a few key football players to stand up to the drug culture in the NFL,  get real testing  that would clean up the NFL and allow a drug free player to compete. Looks like Manning is not the standup guy that I was hoping for. Maybe the next player that gets implicated will be the guy I am looking for that will out the NFL drug culture.
Chris the problem with Sly's statement is its hearsay. So it is inadmissible. That is how a judge would deal with his statements.
I do not think so. Sly's connection to Manning came through his brief employment at at the Guyer Institute.

A really smart person would make sure no banned drugs were sent to his home addressed to anyone there. I don't think he's as smart as some people make him out to be. He's smart enough to outwit defenses and make Papa John commercials and buy pizza franchises in a state that just legalized pot, but maybe not so smart when he hires a cannon to kill a mosquito (hail Confuscious.)

I hear congressmen and presidential candidates saying they want to bring down the cost of insurance. I never hear them say they want to bring down the cost of prescription drugs, nor end priv=ce fixing, nor make the cost of medical care transparent. The problem is not the cost of insurance. The problem is the cost of healthcare and the lack of transparency. How can we have a free market when no ones the cost upfront.

U.S. DOT Launches First-Ever National Distracted Driving Enforcement and Advertising Campaign

http://www.nhtsa.gov/About+NHTSA/Press+Releases/2014/DOT+Launches+First-...

Good grief.

1) Deaths by gun violence have overtaken vehicular deaths.
2) Cars have a very ordinary purpose and function in the lives of most Americans, unless we are willing to spend for vast increases in public (including freight) transportation.

The number killed in car accidents and the number killed by guns is just about level and in some states the latter is higher.  But no matter how you cut it, cars are not manufactured with the purpose of killing.  Guns are.  Yes, people who text and drive are not being very smart.  I wonder, TWB, whether you ever talk to a passenger in your car while driving?  Do you ever look over at that person?  Do you tune your radio?  Do you sip a cup of coffee or take a bite of a donut while driving?  Do you glance at your watch or the GPS unit?  If you do, you're distracted from driving.  Not very smart.

More folks are killed in traffic accidents than in gun violence. I believe that many of these accidents result from a distracted driver using a cell phone.
Now that a tearful Mr. Obama has addressed the gun issue, let us hope he becomes equally enthusiastic about eliminating causes of accidental death on our roadways.
My feeling is that anyone wishing to purchase a cell phone should be subjected to a background check to determine that he/she is able to demonstrate a minimal level of intelligence, IQ, and common sense. This applicant should be able to provide documentation to prove that he/she has the proper judgement, intellect, and common sense to turn off his/her cell phone while driving.
Drivers texting on cell phones kill many more than lunatics with guns. How about some tears for these victims? Or, as I suspect, is this just politics as usual. SSDD! No wonder the popularity of Mr. Trump. Folks are sick to death of the Washington establishment. Lies, deceit, and more lies.

Not any law, this particular law. 2nd amendment is an anachronistic law that that has served it's purpose (if at all it had any) long ago and does not have a place in a mature democracy like ours with well established and proven methods of ensuring a government that is for the people, by the people and of the people. It has become a tool of vested interests who use it as a mask of misplaced nationalism and American individualism to serve their own narrow purposes.

Various military and civilian arms dating from 1897 to present. Everything from antique Winchesters and S&W revolvers, military rifles from WWI and WWII, to many modern firearms like "Tactical" pistols made by Heckler and Koch , "Assault Weapons" like AR-15's and Ruger Mini 14, SKS, etc., etc. I usually limit myself to firearms of historical interest or significance.

The guns I own for defensive use and licenced concealed carry are the best, most modern, and most reliable money can buy. If they happen to utilize detachable magazines holding more than 10, 20, or 30 rounds, a semi-automatic function, or scary cosmetic features, so be it.
